posts.cooked:
I compiled Urho3D for 4 hours straight today, and when it was done the samples are a bit…off.

sad.jpg974×1200 339 KB

I was following the MinGW Windows guide.

If you know what happened help would be much appreciated, thank you.

Specs: (if needed)
OS: Windows 10
Processor: AMD FX™-6300 Six-Core Processor, 3500 Mhz, 3 Core(s), 6 Logical Processor(s)
System Type: x64-based PC
GPU: GeForce GTX 760

link_counts.title: Compiling Urho3D on Windows · urho3d/Urho3D Wiki · GitHub

posts.cooked:
Just a GCC 8 issue. See:

Problems with 3D samples on Win10 Support
I used MinGW from Stephan Lavavej’s site to compile Urho3D on Windows 7 and it worked just fine. Now I’ve updated to Windows 10 and successfully compiled the lib. Used default options (OpenGL renderer) with cmake_mingw.bat build -DMINGW_SYSROOT=C:\MinGW. 2D samples works fine, but 3D ones do not. Here’s how 13_CharacterDemo.exe looks like: [Urho3D] It’s upside-down, model is squashed and moving the mouse causes it to be stretched into infinity. What is going on here?
github.com/urho3d/Urho3D

Rendering issues

opened 05:31PM - 09 Nov 18 UTC
closed 10:58AM - 10 Nov 18 UTC
LL2
duplicate

I've cloned and compiled Urho3d 1.7 a week or so ago and after recompiling my ol…d project i'm getting issues with the camera or renderer. The camera is upside down and when i move the mouse, the projection seems to be corrupted. this is not only happening with my old projects, but also with the Urho's demos. Here an example with CharacterDemo: ![](https://media.giphy.com/media/1wo0BIpxjhJsUnNQ51/giphy.gif) https://media.giphy.com/media/1wo0BIpxjhJsUnNQ51/giphy.gif I'm using Ubuntu Mate 18.10 (Cosmic Cuttlefish)

github.com/urho3d/Urho3D

Fix for #2326

urho3d:master ← alex-rass-88:master
opened 08:36AM - 03 Jul 18 UTC
alex-rass-88
+3 -5

Remove '-ffast-math' option. Remove GCC 8.x check in Matrix3x4.h -ffast-math… dangerous option.

github.com/urho3d/Urho3D

gcc 8.1 incorrect code

opened 02:49PM - 07 Jun 18 UTC
closed 11:32AM - 05 Jul 18 UTC
alex-rass-88
bug

Bug in gcc 8.1. Incorrect code is being compiled. It's like an inside-out image.… ![06-bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7008147/41107292-c0998e66-6a7a-11e8-9294-cd81c40d8aa8.png) In gcc 7.3 normal: ![06-norm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7008147/41107323-cebc966e-6a7a-11e8-8fad-1a90babb0c4c.png) How to get workaround the problem I do not know yet. So keep in mind.

link_counts.title: Fix for #2326 by alex-rass-88 · Pull Request #2344 · urho3d/Urho3D · GitHub

posts.cooked: A new release should probably be made to get rid of the 1.7 release. Or instruct people to use the repository since that’s more stable anyways.

posts.name: Leith Ketchell
posts.cooked: Ideally, we should be performing regular builds, and publishing a link to the latest build, with a more informed version identifier. But there is in my mind, a real need to maintain a link to the last known stable version as well, because as we’ve seen recently, sometimes bugs creep in that break core stuff like the editor, while the older version may still be usable even in the context of the latest codebase.

posts.name: Yao Wei Tjong
posts.cooked: I have seen enough of this. I see if I can do a backport of the fix to 1.7 and release it as 1.7.1. We don’t do backporting in the past, but I think we can make an exception just for this one. It will be a good exercise anyway before we release 1.8.

posts.name: Arnis Lielturks
posts.cooked: @weitjong Mentioned that we could create 1.8rc. Is that still an option? It’s been almost 2 years since the last release and I think we need to proceed with that.

posts.name: Yao Wei Tjong
posts.cooked: Think we need to close a number of critical open issues and PR before we are ready to talk about releasing 1.8-RC. On my side this include the Gradle custom plugin development, SDL2 upgrade, fixing Web-build with latest EMSDK.

posts.name: Vitalii
posts.cooked:
@weitjong, Thanks for the release!

Btw, you might want to announce the release on all the usual channels:

Urho3D

Latest news

Urho3D is a free lightweight, cross-platform 2D and 3D game engine implemented in C++ and released under the MIT license. Greatly inspired by OGRE and Horde3D.

posts.name: Yao Wei Tjong
posts.cooked: This is actually only a bug fix release of 1.7. But I could post something there as well after I verified all the release automation still functions as expected.
Should I use the repo?

posts.name: J Tippetts
posts.cooked: I highly recommend all to use the repo. It’s pretty stable, and 1.7 is getting pretty long in the tooth.
Alrighty, thanks for letting me know.
Sorry for doublepost, but uhh how do I compile it for MinGW with code::blocks? Thanks.

posts.name: Yao Wei Tjong
posts.cooked:
Use the provided convenient batch file or script for invoking CMake. For your case it is “cmake_codeblocks.bat”.

BTW, the release automation seems to be largely intact. CI release build on a few of the platforms failed but that was caused by the CI could not find the old compiler toolchain expected by build script in 1.7.1 tag and nothing to do with the quality of the new tag. This is something preventable in the future. So, yeah, I learnt one or two lessons in this exercise that will make the future releases better.
I don’t see that bat in the repo.

posts.name: Yao Wei Tjong
posts.cooked: It is in the “script” directory now in the master branch.
Oh, okay thanks haha.
Thanks everyone, the examples are working as intended.
